explanation: OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: Macro expansion could evaluate or modify its arguments (e.g. perform assignments or side effects). To prove the function does not modify the parameter or the object it points to we must inspect the macro definition. OS_object_token_t: The type of *token determines whether dereferencing the pointer yields an lvalue that could be modified by OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET or other code; also confirms the const qualification and whether the pointee is mutable. OS_impl_mutex_table: The table/object used by OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET — its type/definition shows whether the macro might perform writes into the table or into the provided index/pointer. OS_impl_mutex_internal_record_t: The type of the returned 'impl' (and its members) confirms that taking the address of impl->id (and passing it to pthread_mutex_lock) does not involve modifying the token or the token pointee. pthread_mutex_lock: The prototype/behavior confirms that the call cannot modify 'token' (only the mutex object) and has no hidden side-effects on the parameter. Together these symbols let an analyst determine whether any expression in the function (macro expansion, dereference, or function call) can modify the pointer parameter itself or the const-qualified pointee.
